required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Maternal and Fetal Outcomes Following Influenza Vaccination in Pregnancy
clinical_study.official_title: Maternal and Fetal Outcomes Following Influenza Vaccination in Pregnancy

collaborator.agency: Government-wide R&D Fund project for infectious disease research (GFID)

brief_summary.textblock: This is a nationwide cohort study to assess maternal and fetal outcomes following vaccination with a quadrivalent influenza vaccine (QIV) during pregnancy.

detailed_description.textblock: The Korean National Immunization Program (NIP) first introduced quadrivalent influenza immunization for all pregnant women in the 2020-2021 season. This nationwide cohort study is proposed to assess the risks of adverse maternal and fetal outcomes following vaccination with a quadrivalent influenza vaccine (QIV) during pregnancy. We will use the national health insurance database from the National Health Insurance Service (NHIS) linked with the national immunization program registry data from the Korea Centers for Diseases Control & Prevention (KCDC).

primary_outcome.time_frame: from delivery up to 1 year after birth
primary_outcome.description: Spontaneous abortion, stillbirth, neonatal death, congenital anomaly, pre-term birth, fetal growth restriction, small for gestational age, and low birth weight, which are confirmed by diagnostic records in the NHIS database.

primary_outcome.time_frame: from delivery up to 1 year after birth
primary_outcome.description: Vaccine-related adverse events confirmed by diagnostic records in the NHIS database.

primary_outcome.measure: Risk of poor health outcomes in pregnant women
primary_outcome.time_frame: from delivery up to 1 year after birth
primary_outcome.description: Hospital admission, emergency department visits, influenza infection, and hospitalization with influenza infection, which are confirmed by diagnosis and healthcare utilization records in the NHIS database.

primary_outcome.measure: Risk of poor health outcomes in neonates
primary_outcome.time_frame: from delivery up to 1 year after birth
primary_outcome.description: Respiratory distress, neonatal intensive care unit admission, and hospital visits with neonatal infection or fever, which are confirmed by diagnosis and healthcare utilization records in the NHIS database.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from delivery up to 1 year after birth
secondary_outcome.description: Pre-eclampsia/eclampsia, gestational diabetes mellitus, antenatal bleeding, postpartum hemorrhage, and maternal death, which are confirmed by diagnostic records in the NHIS database.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Pregnant women vaccinated with a QIV
arm_group.description: Women aged 20-44 years who had received a QIV during their pregnancy between September 22, 2020, and April 30, 2021, under the national immunization program in South Korea.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Pregnant women unvaccinated with a QIV
arm_group.description: Women aged 20-44 years who had not received a QIV during their pregnancy between September 22, 2020, and April 30, 2021, under the national immunization program in South Korea.

intervention.description: quadrivalent influenza vaccination in the flu seasons
intervention.arm_group_label: Pregnant women unvaccinated with a QIV
Pregnant women vaccinated with a QIV

study_pop.textblock: Pregnant women during the period of the national immunization program in South Korea.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women between September 22, 2020, and April 30, 2021.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Women aged <20 or >45 years
- Pregnancies with a chromosomal abnormality
- Pregnancies with exposure to a known teratogenic medication

reference.citation: Baum U, Leino T, Gissler M, Kilpi T, Jokinen J. Epub 2020 Sep 21. Review.

Health outcomes of young children born to mothers who received 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza vaccination during pregnancy: retrospective cohort study. BMJ. 2019 Jul 10;366:l4151. doi: 10.1136/bmj.l4151.
